name: John Oates
description:
'''John William Oates''' (born April 7, 1948) is an American musician, best known as half of the rock and soul duo [[Hall & Oates]] along with [[Daryl Hall]]. He has played [[Rock music|rock]], [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]], and [[Soul music|soul]] music, serving as a guitarist, singer, songwriter, and record producer.

Although Oates' primary role in the duo was being the guitarist, he also co-wrote many of the top 10 songs that they recorded, including: "[[Sara Smile]]" (referring to Hall's then-girlfriend, [[Sara Allen]]), "[[She's Gone (Hall & Oates song)|She's Gone]]", and "[[Out of Touch (song)|Out of Touch]]", as well as "[[You Make My Dreams]]", "[[I Can't Go for That (No Can Do)]]", "[[Maneater (Hall & Oates song)|Maneater]]", and "[[Adult Education (song)|Adult Education]]". He also sang lead vocals on several more singles in the [[Billboard Hot 100|Hot 100]], such as "[[Voices (Hall & Oates album)#Singles|How Does It Feel to Be Back]]", "[[You've Lost That Lovin' Feelin']]" (a remake of the 1965 song performed by [[the Righteous Brothers]]), and "[[Big Bam Boom#Singles|Possession Obsession]]". In 1986, Oates contributed the song "(She's the) Shape of Things to Come" on the soundtrack to the 1986 film ''[[About Last Night (1986 film)|About Last Night]]''. He also co-wrote and sang backup on the song "[[Electric Blue (Icehouse song)|Electric Blue]]", recorded by the Australian band [[Icehouse (band)|Icehouse]], which was a ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' top 10 hit.

Oates was inducted into the [[Songwriters Hall of Fame]] in 2004, and in 2014 was inducted into the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]], as a member of Hall & Oates. His memoir, ''Change of Seasons'', was published in 2017.
